default: a {@item leather armor|phb} with a longcoat
a {@item dagger|phb} and (a) a handgun and 20 {@item bullet|MFOV:GS|bullets} or (b) a revolver and 10 {@item bullet|MFOV:GS|bullets}
Any two-handed firearm that isn't heavy and 30 {@item bullet|MFOV:GS|bullets} or {@item shell|MFOV:GS|shells}
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) one kit you're proficient with

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: You adopt a particular style of gunfighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

entries.name: Akimbo
entries: When you engage in two-weapon fighting with firearms, you do not take a penalty to the damage of the second attack.

entries.name: Bullseye
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to ranged attack rolls you make using firearms. The weapon must have the Sighted property or have a normal range of 80 feet or longer to gain this effect. This effect does not stack with the Archery fighting style.

entries.name: Duelist
entries: While you are wielding a firearm in one hand and nothing in the other, if you make a ranged weapon attack and exceed the target's AC by 5 or more, you deal an additional die of weapon damage. You can only use this ability once per round.

entries.name: Shotgunner
entries: When you hit with a ranged weapon attack using a firearm that has the Scatter property, you can reroll the lowest damage die, and you must use the new roll, even if the new roll is worse than the original.

classFeature.name: Quick Draw
entries: Gunslingers have twitch reflexes and can pull a gun in the blink of an eye. You have advantage on initiative rolls. Additionally, you can draw or stow up to two weapons when you roll initiative and whenever you take an action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Critical Shot
entries: At 2nd level, your ranged firearm attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

classFeature.name: Poker Face
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you have advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to prevent others from sensing your motives, perceiving your emotions, or reading your thoughts.

classFeature.name: Risk
entries: By 2nd level, you can perform incredible feats of daring that are fueled by special dice called risk dice.

entries.name: Risk Dice
entries: You have four risk dice, which are d8s. You gain additional risk dice, and your risk dice change as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Risk Dice column of the Gunslinger table. You regain all expended risk dice when you take a long rest.

entries.name: Using Risk Dice
entries: Once on each of your turns, you can expend a risk die to perform a Deed of your choice. Your deed options are detailed at the end of the class description.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: Some of your deeds require your target to make a saving throw to resist the deed's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

classFeature.name: Gunslinger's Creed
entries: By the time gunslingers reach 3rd level, they embrace a way of living, known as their creed, which guides their judgments and their unique brand of gunslinging. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 10th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Gut Shot
entries: Starting at 6th level, whenever you score a critical hit on a Large or smaller creature using a firearm, the target of that attack is incapacitated until the beginning of your next turn. Elementals, oozes, and undead are immune to this effect.

classFeature.name: Creed Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger's Creed.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a red dragon's fiery breath or an ice storm spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Critical Shot Improvement
entries: Starting at 9th level, your ranged firearm attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 18 to 20.

classFeature.name: Creed Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger's Creed.

classFeature.name: Mankiller
entries: At 11th level, when you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn, you can add your ability score modifier to firearm damage rolls.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Dire Gambit
entries: Starting at 13th level, whenever you score a critical hit, you regain one expended risk die.

classFeature.name: Creed Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Gunslinger's Creed.

classFeature.name: Cheat Death
entries: By 15th level, you have a knack for escaping the reaper. When you would be reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction and expend one risk die to avoid being incapacitated and instead be reduced to a number of hit points equal to the number rolled on the die.
Once you use this ability, you must finish a short or long rest before using it again.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Critical Shot Improvement
entries: Starting at 17th level, your ranged firearm attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 17 to 20.

classFeature.name: Maverick
entries: By 18th level, you are unshakable. You have advantage on Constitution checks and saving throws.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeature.name: Head Shot
entries: At 20th level, when you score a critical hit against a creature using a firearm, you can choose for this shot to be a head shot. If the creature has less than 100 hit points, it dies. Otherwise, it takes {@damage 10d10} additional damage. Elementals, oozes, undead, and creatures which lack nervous systems or vital organs take no additional damage from this ability.
Once you use this ability, you must finish a short or long rest before using it again.

subclassFeature.name: Pistolero
entries: Bullets are power, and you have long believed that more bullets equal more power. Your expertise is in delivering a hail of deadly fire to pulverize your enemies. Not every bullet needs to be accurate to make a difference.

subclassFeature.name: Point Blank Shot
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you don't suffer disadvantage from making a ranged attack with a firearm while you are within 5 feet of a hostile creature.

subclassFeature.name: Fan the Hammer
entries: At 3rd level, when you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn to attack with a firearm, you can use your bonus action to make two additional firearm attacks with disadvantage. These additional attacks always have disadvantage, regardless of circumstance. This weapon can't have the Automatic or Two-Handed property.

The number of bonus attacks you can make with disadvantage increases as you gain levels in this class. At 10th level, you can make 3 additional attacks and at 14th level you can make 4 additional attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Speed Loader
entries: Starting at 7th level, you have mastered the art of quickly reloading your weapon. On your turn, you can reload a single one-handed firearm without using an action or bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Bullet Time
entries: At 10th level, when you make a firearm attack with a one-handed firearm on your turn, you can use your bonus action to gain advantage on the attack roll. Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Swift Vengeance
entries: At 14th level, when you take damage from a creature within 15 feet of you, you can use your reaction to make a firearm attack targeting that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Sharpshooter
entries: A well-placed bullet is more powerful than a sword, arrow, or spell. Indeed, you believe that every violent conflict should sound like a single loud crack followed by a long silence. Such shots need to be delivered perfectly, even at range, for when they are done right, they are as deadly for the target as they are stupendous for the audience.

subclassFeature.name: Aim
entries: Starting at 3rd level, as a bonus action on your turn, you can take the {@action Aim} action. When you take this action, your next firearm attack suffers no penalty for long range, and ignores half and three-quarters cover.

subclassFeature.name: Eagle Eye
entries: At 3rd level, you can see better from far away. You gain proficiency in in the {@skill Perception} skill, if you did not have it already, and you can add twice your proficiency modifier to Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks you make that rely on sight.

subclassFeature.name: Camouflage
entries: By 7th level, you've learned to expertly conceal yourself with foliage and leaves. You can spend one minute to prepare camouflage for yourself. Until you move, you have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks you make to hide among vegetation.

subclassFeature.name: Utility Shot
entries: At 10th level, you can quickly and precisely shoot objects. As an action, you can make a firearm attack targeting a Tiny object within the firearm's range which isn't being worn or carried, such as a rope, chain, belt, wooden rod, candle, bottle, or lock. This object is considered to have an AC of 10. On a hit, a nonmagical object is destroyed instantly and a magical object is flung 15 feet away.

subclassFeature.name: Focus
entries: Starting at 14th level, whenever you take the {@action Aim} action on your turn followed by the Attack action, you can choose to make only one firearm attack. This attack is made with advantage and deals critical damage on a hit.

entries.name: Automatic
entries: When you make an attack with this weapon on your turn, you can choose to make two attacks with disadvantage instead. These attacks always have disadvantage, regardless of circumstance. These attacks use double the normal amount of ammunition.

entries.name: Concealable
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks made to hide this weapon.

entries.name: Foregrip
entries: This weapon can be used with one or two hands. If used in two hands, its normal and long ranges double.

entries.name: Mounted
entries: This weapon is normally used while attached to a tripod, vehicle, or other bracing mount. You can mount or unmount this weapon as an action. While it is mounted, it can't be moved. It can only be used to make an attack while unmounted if held by a Medium or larger creature with a Strength score of at least 15.

entries.name: Reload
entries: This weapon can be used to make a number of attacks before it must be reloaded. If you are not proficient with the weapon, reloading it takes an action. If you are proficient, you can reload it as a bonus action. Some weapons require longer to reload, even if you have proficiency, which is specified in the reload property. If reloading a weapon requires longer than one action, the weapon can't be used to make attacks until reloading is finished.

entries.name: Scatter
entries: If you make an attack against a target that is within half this weapon's normal range, you deal the damage value listed in parentheses instead of the weapon's normal damage dice.

entries.name: Sighted
entries: This weapon has disadvantage on attack rolls made against targets within 20 feet.

A glass falls, clattering to the floor, and the tavern grows silent. A dwarf with a deep scowl, dripping with freshly spilled beer, leers at a drunken nearby orc and fingers for a pair of revolvers at his waist.
High on a hillside, carefully concealed beneath foliage and stones, a rifleman steadies his breathing and adjusts his scope, acquiring his target and patiently awaiting his moment to strike.

Risk is in a gunslinger's blood. They are bold renegades, bucking tradition and forging a new path with dangerous and inelegant firearms. Gunslingers are infamous for surviving by their wits, relying on split-second timing and a considerable amount of luck to survive.

entries.name: Guts and Gunpowder
entries: Black powder is not for the faint of heart. Its thunderous applause is volatile and imprecise; a barely-controlled explosion directed at an enemy. Only the truly fearless seek to master it, for one must be mad or have nerves of steel to weather the risk of its use. But those who call themselves gunslingers are fearless combatants, hurling death from their guns in a roaring cacophony. Adapted for shootouts, gunslingers are mobile and daring, knowing that life or death hangs on snap decision making and one's own mettle.

entries.name: Dangerous Outsiders
entries: A gunslinger's explosive lifestyle lends well to wandering and adventuring. Gunslingers will often shoot first and ask questions later, an attitude which earns them few friends and bountiful enemies. In their travels, most gunslingers are secretive and take lengths go unnoticed, lest they be spotted by old foes with scores to settle.

Yet, their skills are not unneeded. Anyone requiring protection or revenge of their own can count on a gunslinger to be in need of an odd job when they roll into town. After all, skill with a gun is always in demand somewhere.

entries.name: Creating a Gunslinger
entries: When creating your gunslinger, consider where firearms fit in the world and the common perceptions of those who use them. If firearms are the norm, gunslingers might be mercenaries or militiamen. If firearms are rare, your gunslinger might be one of a kind, a trailblazer in new types of warfare.
It's also not unusual for a gunslinger to be haunted by their past. Did some event drive you to the gun and motivate you to travel? Is there a bounty on your head in one or more areas?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: To make a gunslinger quickly, follow these suggestions. Make Dexterity and Constitution your highest ability scores. If you plan to choose the Pistolero creed, make Constitution higher, or if you plan to choose the Sharpshooter, make Dexterity higher.

entries.name: Gunslinger
